Thereâ€™s many words that could use a little tweaking to make their meaning a little more clear or at least, a little more descriptive in terms of the reality they describe. Adding or deleting a single character (as in â€˜healthscareâ€™) or changing a syllable slightly (as in â€˜politricksâ€™) brings us closer to a wordâ€™s true meaning.

Iâ€™m convinced the thought that fills my mind most of the time is just a complex of [reactions](reactions.md) to the strange world Iâ€™m living in. Creative [urges](urges-1.md) struggle to redirect my mind to what I donâ€™t see, to what might be. I want to deal with whatâ€™s possible, not wallow is whatâ€™s already taken place and left its ugly mark.

She told us there were liberals living next door as if we would think that was bad thing. â€œThey didn't like the sign in our yard.â€ Funny how easy it is to be so full of yourself that you think others would have to agree with you. You're on the right side of history after all. How could anyone not agree?
Then again, one's own experience or perspective might come into play here - I know - Iâ€™m kinda silly...
Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of areaâ€™s first, specializing in [Italian subs](sub.md), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. Itâ€™s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.

To be honest, Iâ€™m not sure if it was the Delaware Bay or the Chesapeake Bay but Tony and my father had these huge cages for catching crabs and weâ€™d return [home](above%20the%20sub%20shop.md) with bushels of â€™em.
and I know how to make one!
When we discovered Sliding Rock, we had not bathed for days camping up in the mountains. The cold plunge pool below was totally rejuvenating.

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when Iâ€™m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. Itâ€™s a tough road to drive on but Iâ€™ve got a decent set of wheels with a few bells and whistles and more important, I enjoy the driving.

It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasnâ€™t anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! Iâ€™m [guessing](shatters.md) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](the%20bay.md).
